I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based loan to Armenia for the Infrastructure Sustainability Support Program (Phase 2).1 
The report also describes the proposed technical assistance (TA) for Supporting Implementation 
of Phase 2 of the Infrastructure Sustainability Support Program, and if the Board approves the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA.2 
 
2.  The proposed program aims to improve infrastructure operation and sustainability in 
Armenia through reforms in the road, water, and power sectors. The program will achieve this 
through  introducing  program  budgeting,  improved  regulation,  increased  budget  and  other 
allocations for maintenance, improved contracting and maintenance practices and institutions 
for infrastructure service delivery, and increased power sector revenue generation. Greater 
financial  sustainability  of  power  and  water  utilities  will  reduce  fiscal  stress  and  contingent 
liabilities. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Armenia faces economic challenges and a tight fiscal situation. Although Armenia’s 
real gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an annual average of 4.7% from 2010 to 2014, the 
economy  remains  vulnerable  to  external  shocks  because  of  its  narrow  export  base  and 
dependence on remittance inflows. With the onset of the recession in the Russian Federation, 
and lowering export demand from its main trading partners, GDP growth moderated from 3.5% 
in 2014 to 3.0% in 2015 and is expected to drop to 2.2% in 2016. Plummeting remittance inflows 
prompted a 30% depreciation of the dram in November 2014. Declining fiscal revenues related 
to lower import tax revenues and rising public expenditures resulted in a surging budget deficit 
that reached 4.8% of GDP in 2015 from 2.1% in 2014. The deficit is forecast to reach 4.1% in 
2016, possibly higher if economic conditions worsen. In concert with the International Monetary 
Fund (IMF), the government plans to reduce the budget deficit to 2.8% of GDP in 2017 through 
aggressive prioritization of public expenditures and increasing revenues through a new tax 
code.3 The public debt—GDP ratio is expected to increase from 43.5% in 2014 to 54.0% in 2017 
and, in line with IMF projections, is expected to moderate to 52.2% by 2021 (footnote 3). Public 
debt  service  is  expected  to  increase  from  3.6%  of  GDP  in  2015  to  4.2%  in  2017.  The 
government’s  fiscal  consolidation  limits  budget  allocations  for  infrastructure  investment, 
operation, and maintenance in the foreseeable future, emphasizing the need for improved cost 
recovery, generation of alternative revenues, and better management of fiscal resources. 
 
4.  Infrastructure sustainability is important for inclusive growth. Although Armenia’s 
poverty head count improved from 35% in 2011 to 30% in 2014, the incidence of income 
poverty remains high and is likely to increase in the context of the ongoing decline in growth.4 
Providing adequate infrastructure services is critical to supporting economic activity and income

Support Program, Phase 2 (TA 9065-ARM). 
3  IMF. 2016. Armenia: Third Review Under the Extended Arrangement, and Request for Waiver and Modification of

2 
generation, especially outside the capital city. Rural Armenia is home to 37% of the population, 
and 36% of the labor force is active in agriculture. However, agriculture contributes only 19% to 
GDP (2015), as many farms engage in subsistence activities and many self-employed people 
are trapped in low-productivity jobs. The poverty head count in secondary towns and rural areas 
of 32% (2015) points to underserved regions, which suffer from poor transport connectivity and 
low quality of infrastructure and utility services. As of 2014, a significant part of the rural 
population had to travel more than 10 kilometers (km) to reach agricultural markets (57%), 
banks (47%), and hospitals (44%) (footnote 4). As rural households primarily access such 
services by vehicle, the poor condition of roads is an important factor impeding economic 
activity in Armenia’s regions. While 96% of the urban population is serviced by private water 
concession contracts and benefit from adequate sanitation, only 78% of the rural population 
does.5 Armenia has 100% access to electricity, but this is being threatened by the lack of 
necessary  capital  to  fund  the  rehabilitation  of  aging  power  infrastructure.  Aging  public 
infrastructure, limited fiscal resources and the lack of adequate prioritization and management 
of scarce public resources, limit opportunities for inclusive growth, especially in the regions. 
 
5.  Road network sustainability issues. Armenia’s road network is 7,531 km long, of 
which 1,759 km (23.4%) are interstate roads connecting Armenia to its neighbors, 1,966 km 
(26.1%) are republican roads that connect major cities and towns, and 3,806 km (50.5%) are 
rural roads.6 The interstate roads have deteriorated substantially with 30% classified in poor 
condition in 2014, up from 6% in 2010, while the republican roads improved, with 22% of roads 
classified as poor in 2014 down from 49% in 2010 (footnote 6). It is estimated that 60% of local 
roads require rehabilitation and that only 66% of communities have a satisfactory connection 
with republican or interstate roads (footnote 6).  
 
6.  Road maintenance budget allocations are insufficient to adequately maintain the road 
network and limit further deterioration. However, opportunities exist to improve maintenance by 
streamlining functions of government agencies and coordinating maintenance and rehabilitation, 
improving information on the maintenance status, and prioritizing maintenance needs. The 
Armenian  Roads  Directorate  (ARD),  which  is  currently  an  agency  under  the  Ministry  of 
Transport,  Communication  and  Information  Technology  (MOTCIT),  requires  significant 
strengthening, gearing it toward a gradual evolution into an independent body that is able to 
attract  and  retain  qualified  staff  to  fulfill  its  mandate.  Currently,  the  ARD’s  mandate  is 
undermined by its subordination under MOTCIT, focusing on managing maintenance contracts 
and lacking prioritization of maintenance expenditures. The existing public contract laws under 
which the ARD outsources road maintenance work to private companies need to be amended to 
permit performance-based contracts and more flexibility.  
 
7.  Water supply sustainability issues. Since 2002, the government has carried out major 
reforms in the water supply and sanitation sector. The State Committee for Water Economy 
(SCWE)  was  established  and  urban  water  supply  has  been  contracted  to  private 
concessionaires, which has expanded to 92% of the service coverage in urban areas covered 
by  the  concessionaires.  However,  tariff  revenues  are  insufficient  to  cover  operation  and 
maintenance costs and the government provides an annual $12.6 million equivalent to meet the 
revenue shortfall. This does not include debt service and full maintenance expenditures which 
                                                
5  World Bank. 2016. World Development Indicators 2016. Washington, DC. 
6  Government of Armenia. 2015. Maintenance Financing Strategy for the State Roads of General Use of the 
Republic of Armenia. Yerevan.

3 
lead  to  significant  fiscal  contingent  liabilities. 7 The  revenue  of  water  utilities  would  be 
significantly improved if nonrevenue water (NRW) caused by leakage and improper metering of 
urban condominiums was eliminated. It is estimated that 183 million cubic meters or $67 million 
could be recovered annually from users, which would provide significant fiscal savings while 
improving utility services through revenues generated by the concessionaire. In addition, 560 
rural communities representing 8% of the population are serviced through inadequate local 
water supply systems that require significant investment to reduce water rationing. 
 
8.  The Armenia Water Supply and Sanitation Strategy (2015) emphasized that revenues 
for water supply and sanitation services would need to rise by 140% by 2030 to recover the full 
cost of supply and debt service.8 As for sanitation, only 4 of the 20 wastewater treatment plants 
are  operating,  indicating  the  urgent  need  for  replacement  investment.  The  situation  is 
particularly severe in rural areas where waste is untreated and stored in cesspits. The strategy 
estimates the cost for water and sanitation investments for communities connected to the piped 
network at $1.32 billion and for unconnected communities, $1.23 billion.  
 
9.  Power  sector  sustainability  issues.  Since  the  mid-1990s  the  government  has 
implemented a number of significant reforms in the power sector, including (i) unbundling the 
vertically integrated power sector into generation, transmission, and distribution companies; (ii) 
privatizing power and gas distribution, and most power generating companies;9 (iii) promoting 
renewable energy; and (iv) maintaining a cost recovery tariff. However, Armenia’s installed 
capacity  is  4,336  megawatts  (2015)  of  which  only  2,589  megawatts  or  59%  is  currently 
available, and power transmission and distribution reliability and efficiency is undermined by 
assets that are more than 30 years old. Armenia’s single-buyer structure does not support 
national or regional trade of seasonal surplus capacity, which has led to suboptimal energy use 
and pricing. Establishing wholesale and export trading, and thus market-based pricing, would 
attract private sector investment and improve power sector sustainability. 
 
10.  Utility  regulation  issues.  Established  in  1997,  the  Public  Services  Regulatory 
Commission  (PSRC)  is  a  multi-utility  regulator  covering  energy,  water,  electronic 
communications, as well as postal services and railways. Although it has a well-established 
decision-making  process,  the  PSRC  has  been  criticized  for  not  explaining  sufficiently  the 
rationale for its key tariff decisions. For example, protests over the PSRC’s power price decision 
in 2015 raised concern about the PSRC’s ineffective public communication. This triggered calls 
for a more transparent and accountable PSRC. 
 
11.  The government’s strategy. In its Armenia Development Strategy, 2014–2025, the 
government recognizes the need to improve its management of public infrastructure to improve 
connectivity and utility services, as well as the need for broad public financial management 
(PFM) reforms. It initiated key reforms as described in paras. 12–15.10  
 
12.  Transition  from  line  item  budgeting  to  program  budgeting.  The  government 
recognized that the current line item budgeting is not providing desired performance incentives 
to manage expenditures. By 2018, all government agencies are required to present programs

4 
that include key performance indicators as expenditure triggers. While this approach provides 
more flexibility by the spending units, the units must justify prioritization of budget allocations to 
the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF),  which  retains  its  role  in  allocating  overall  resources  and 
monitoring efficient use of such resources.11 
 
13.  Improving road sector maintenance. To enhance road maintenance, the government 
will introduce performance-based contracts for the ARD contractors. In addition, the ARD will 
concurrently improve its analytical capability to prioritize maintenance expenditures. As the 
current government budget for road maintenance of approximately $23.3 million annually is 
insufficient to reverse the deterioration of road infrastructure, the government envisages an 
expansion of such expenditure within the limited fiscal resources available during 2017–2019.12 
Increased  budget  allocations  for  road  maintenance  are  included  in  the  government’s 
development strategy. 
 
14.  Improving  water  supply  and  sewerage  services  through  a  single  lessor.  The 
signing of a 15-year lease contract with a private single concessionaire covering Armenia’s 
water supply and sanitation system is expected in the fourth quarter of 2016. Despite the urgent 
need to upgrade sanitation assets, limited fiscal resources called for prioritizing water supply 
over sanitation investments. The government’s development strategy focuses on investment in 
water supply, expanding water access to all communities, and full cost recovery. 
 
15.  Attracting  private  investors  and  optimizing  power  usage.  To  introduce  market 
pricing, the government is taking the first step toward a multibuyer–multiseller system through 
third-party access to the power grid. This will allow large customers to purchase power directly 
from generating companies.13 These reforms facilitate regional trade and wholesale trade of 
surplus capacity to generate additional revenues, which makes rehabilitation of the aging assets 
and  investments  in  new  assets  attractive  to  investors. The  reforms  require  legislative  and 
regulatory amendments and investments that upgrade the power grid. Development partners 
are working with the government to address these needs.  
 
16.  ADB’s experience. The support of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for improving 
PFM in infrastructure started with the preparation of the Infrastructure Sustainability Support 
Program in 2012.14 The program focused on institutional reforms to align government agencies 
in the water and road sectors with their responsibilities and avoid duplication of efforts. In the 
MOTCIT, program budgeting was initiated, a road sector council was established to coordinate 
interagency policy and planning, a road sector regulator was created, and a road financing 
strategy was prepared to help identify high-level investment needs. The SCWE prepared a 
water supply financing strategy to help guide future investment, and established a water asset 
management plan and asset registry. Internal audit functions were strengthened in the MOTCIT 
and the SCWE by establishing internal audit committees and preparing risk-based audit plans. 
Although  the  program  reforms  piloted  some  aspects  of  program  budgeting,  additional

capabilities  and  tools  are  required  to  improve  prioritizing  expenditures  which  are  being 
addressed  under  the  program.  The  reforms  to  be  undertaken  in  phase  2  of  the  program 
represent a natural sequence of the progress achieved in phase 1. In terms of investment 
projects,  ADB  is  funding  the  North–South  Corridor,  the  rehabilitation  of  the  M6  highway, 
rehabilitation of water supply systems in 18 towns and 92 villages, and the rehabilitation of the 
power transmission network. ADB’s road investment projects are also supporting institutional 
reforms in ARD in particular improved data collection and monitoring of road network condition. 
 
17.  Lessons learned. Significant investments in infrastructure and ongoing policy dialogue 
have revealed a number of important lessons, which have been incorporated into this program. 
Policy  reforms  must  be  accompanied  by  (i)  reforms  of  involved  agencies  in  building  their 
analytical  capabilities,  and  (ii)  incentives  to  improve  performance.  Private  participation, 
particularly in service delivery, can lead to improved outcomes through more efficient provision 
of  quality  services.  However,  government  monitoring  of  contracts  and  strong  independent 
regulators are vital to ensure sustained service improvements. Improving transparency is an 
important achievement when decision makers understand the benefits of regular engagement 
with affected stakeholders.  
 
18.  ADB’s  value  added  to  the  design  and  implementation  of  the  program.  The 
preparation of phase 2 of the Infrastructure Sustainability Support Program was associated with 
significant  policy  dialogue  leading  to  the  introduction  of  a  value-added  tax  on  diesel  and 
increases in other fuel excise taxes estimated at $63 million over 2017–2019. These measures 
provide fiscal resources for road maintenance expenditure increases of at least $35 million. 
Also, ADB’s policy dialogue provided for maintenance expenditures of $79 million over 15 years 
in the new draft water supply lease contract. A stronger PSRC developed drinking water and 
wastewater regulatory rules in public consultation with beneficiaries. Continuing efforts initiated 
under  the  program,  MOTCIT  and  SCWE  are  now  beginning  to  systematically  implement 
program budgeting and improve investment planning and prioritization. ADB also contributed to 
policy dialogue in power sector reforms and will continue its support in implementing tranche 2 
reforms under the attached TA. This will help upgrade capabilities of the MOTCIT, SCWE, and 
the Ministry of Energy, Industry and Natural Resources (MOEINR) via the rollout of program 
budgeting; support the PSRC  in  establishing market rules for  a  power tariff structure  and 
preparing a power grid code to enable regional power trading; improve ARD’s transparency in 
decision-making, capacity and operational efficiency, and ability to recruit and retain competent 
staff; and build the new investment planning and asset management department in the SCWE.15 
These reforms were also as a result of dialogue through the design of ADB’s investment 
projects, and they support increased sustainability in these projects as well. 
 
19.  Development partner coordination. ADB coordinates its activities with a number of 
development partners. The IMF provided a $116 million extended fund facility in 2014 and 
conducted  its  third  review  in  May  2016.  The  review  concluded  that  the  government’s 
performance was broadly satisfactory and reflected the difficult external conditions, including 
falling remittance inflows and depressed commodity prices. The successful completion of the 
third review provided for the disbursement of $22 million. The IMF’s 4th review is ongoing and 
the IMF is confident that a successful conclusion will be reached with the Armenia authorities, 
and the review will be formally completed after IMF Board consideration on 11 December 2016. 
The World Bank funds (i) the upgrade of local roads that connect to republican and interstate 
                                                
15 A power grid code is a set of technical specifications that defines the parameters for connecting to a power network 
to ensure safe, secure, and proper economic functioning of the power network.

6 
highways, (ii) tax administration reforms, and (iii) power transmission system improvement. The 
United States Agency for International Development supports power sector reforms, tax reform, 
and clean energy initiatives. German development coordination through (i) KfW funds rural 
water supply systems and power transmission between Armenia and Georgia, and (ii) Deutsche 
Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit supports PFM improvements.  
 
20.  Policy-based loan and budget support. The proposed policy-based loan leverages 
multisector  reforms  while  contributing  to  finance  the  budget  deficit  and  ring-fence  specific 
expenditures related to the proposed reforms. The program will be disbursed in two tranches 
and has attached TA. Tranche 1 will focus on (i) improving the independence, transparency, 
and accountability of the PSRC; (ii) increasing funding for maintenance expenditure for road and 
water sectors and improving revenues of private utilities in the water and power sectors; (iii) 
introducing reforms to improve the transparency in decision-making, capacity, and operational 
efficiency of ARD; (iv) strengthening SCWE in asset management and investment planning;, 
and (v) encouraging competition among buyers in the power sector. Tranche 2 will focus on (i) 
rolling out program budgeting across government, with specific support to MOEINR, MOTCIT, 
and SCWE; (ii) increasing the funding of PSRC; and (iii) improving funding for water supply, 
road maintenance, and power distribution. The program will be executed in 2016 and 2017, with 
16 policy actions to be completed in tranche 1 and 18 policy actions in tranche 2. 
 
21.  Economic  benefits  and  adjustment  costs  of  reforms.  The  program  will  lead  to 
increased financing for maintenance and better management of infrastructure assets in the 
road,  water,  and  power  sectors.  Better  maintenance  reduces  the  need  for  rehabilitation. 
Economic benefits will be realized through government cost savings on major rehabilitation 
works, reduced government subsidies to the sectors, and increased tax revenue. Improved 
revenues and tightly managed expenditures create fiscal resources for high-priority needs. 
Road users will gain economic benefits from reduced transportation costs, and water and power 
consumers will benefit from more reliable services. Strengthened regulation of these sectors, 
improved competition in the power sector, and reforms required to export power will have a 
broader positive impact on inclusive growth. Total economic benefits from the program are 
significant and estimated at $339 million during 2016–2019. In addition, the adjustment costs of 
the reforms are estimated at $67 million during 2016–2018.16  
 
22.  Alignment with government and ADB strategies. The program is consistent with the 
Armenia Development Strategy, 2014–2025; the Medium-Term Expenditure Framework, 2016–
2019; and the Republic of Armenia Government Program.17 It is aligned with ADB’s Midterm 
Review of Strategy 2020; Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020; Sustainable Transport Initiative 
Operational Plan; the Energy Policy; country partnership strategy, 2014–2018; and country 
operations business plan, 2016–2018.18  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
23.  The program impact is aligned with improved service delivery in road, water supply and

C.  Outputs 
24.  Output  1:  Improved  public  financial  management  and  utility  regulation.  The 
government will substantially improve PFM through the rollout of program budgeting. Instructed 
by MOF, line agencies will implement program budgeting. Under the program the MOTCIT, 
SCWE, and MOEINR will build requisite capabilities for this purpose. The government will 
improve the PSRC’s independence, transparency, and accountability, and provide adequate 
financing for it to fulfill its mandate. A private concessionaire will be contracted to provide water 
supply services throughout Armenia during 2017–2031, and the PSRC is preparing drinking 
water and wastewater rules and model contracts for approval in 2016.  
 
25.  Output 2: Increased financing and improved operations in the road sector. Annual 
road maintenance expenditure will increase from $23.3 million in 2016 to $42.5 million in 2019—
an annual average increase of 22%. That increase will be fully funded by road users, with the 
introduction of a 20% value-added tax on diesel and an increase in excise taxes on diesel, 
petrol, and compressed natural gas. These measures are estimated to generate $21 million in 
revenues  annually.  The  MOTCIT  will  improve  road  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  via 
strengthening ARD’s transparency in decision-making, capacity and operational efficiency. This 
includes better prioritization through introducing international roughness index calculations as 
part of cost–benefit analysis, broadening the types of maintenance work to be undertaken, using 
simplified performance-based contracts, and providing greater flexibility on the scope and time 
periods covered in road maintenance contracts. To improve critical information for prioritizing 
recurrent and capital expenditures for roads, the MOTCIT will issue traffic count and evaluation 
guidelines, install at least 10 traffic count stations, and undertake a pavement condition survey.  
 
26.  Output 3: Increased financing and improved operations in the water sector. SCWE 
will sign a 15-year lease contract with a private concessionaire to deliver piped drinking water 
across Armenia in 2017. The SCWE will ensure that the signed lease contract with the new 
private water operator will include an allocation for maintenance of at least $79 million for the 
concession period, to be funded from tariff revenues, thereby limiting fiscal contingent liabilities. 
The contract will also include appropriate performance indicators for the daily availability of 
water, reducing NRW and maintaining water quality. NRW is estimated to be as high as 75% 
(footnote 7). Under phase 2 of the Infrastructure Sustainability Support Program, the SCWE has 
set out a plan as the basis for negotiations with the concessionaire to reduce NRW within the 
new lease contract.19 The SCWE will contract annual audits to ensure the concessionaire’s 
compliance with the terms of the contract. To ensure proper management oversight of its 
assets, the SCWE will establish an investment planning and asset management unit. The 
government will also review laws and regulations to improve sanitation services. 
 
27.  Output  4:  Increased  level  of  power  sector  competitiveness  and  revenue 
generation. The MOEINR intends to liberalize the power sector market to make the sector 
financially sustainable and more efficient. It will do this by (i) developing market rules and 
structure that allow broader competition and opportunity for cross-border and interstate trade of 
                                                
19 ADB is currently designing a new urban water supply investment project in Armenia. Through this project, work will 
also be undertaken to strengthen the legal framework related to NRW in condominiums. ADB estimates that NRW 
would drop by 50% if the issue was resolved in condominiums.

8 
surplus seasonal power; (ii) introducing a tariff for the single power distribution company, which 
will allow third parties to access the distribution network, import power, and enable direct 
contracting between power producers and large customers; and (iii) amending the Energy Law 
(2001) to allow greater competition and cross-border and interstate trading. Multiple options for 
a future market structure have been developed and some amendments to the Energy Law are 
being  proposed.  After  consultation  with  stakeholders,  the  government  will  implement  the 
preferred  market  structure  and  submit  amendments  to  the  Energy  Law  to  the  National 
Assembly. The amendments are also necessary to ensure compliance with European Union 
obligations to enable power trading with the European Union network. The PSRC will introduce 
a grid code to improve transmission and distribution network operations for the system operator 
and  ensure  technically  sound  cross-border  trading.  Finally,  the  government  will  appoint 
independent directors to the boards of wholly-owned power corporations, with at least one 
woman director, to ensure sustainability of reforms through a stronger corporate structure. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
28.  The government has requested a policy-based loan of $90 million to help finance the 
program. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years, a straight-line 
repayment  method,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The average loan 
maturity is 9.25 years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. The loan will be 
released in two tranches, subject to compliance with the agreed tranche release conditions. The 
first tranche of $60 million will be released upon loan effectiveness, while the second tranche of 
$30 million will be released once tranche conditions have been met. The size of the program is 
based on the financing needs of Armenia, the development impact of the policy reform package, 
and the development spending arising from the reform. With a projected budget deficit of 4.1% 
of GDP for 2016, possibly higher if economic conditions worsen, the government plans to 
borrow $599 million in 2016 and $503 million in 2017. ADB’s $60 million loan disbursement will 
finance 10% of the borrowing requirements for 2016 and the $30 million disbursement in 2017 
will finance 6% of the required borrowing. Development expenditure on roads, water supply, and 
power is currently projected to be $128 million in 2016 and $131 million in 2017 (Medium-Term 
Expenditure Framework 2017–2019). The program will finance 47% of this expenditure in 2016 
and 23% in 2017. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
29.  The MOF is the executing agency and the MOF, MOEINR, MOTCIT, PSRC, and SCWE 
are implementing agencies. The MOF will oversee the implementation of the program. The 
proceeds of the loan will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2015, as amended from time to time). ADB will monitor program implementation by review 
missions  and  discussion  of  progress  with  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies.  The 
implementation of the program is expected to be completed by 31 December 2017. 
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
30.  TA is required to assist the government in implementing tranche 2. The MOF is the 
executing agency and the MOF, MOEINR, MOTCIT, PSRC, and SCWE are implementing 
agencies. The TA will require an estimated 47 person-months of expert services, including an 
estimated 14 person-months of international and 33 person-months of national expert services. 
The  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of

9 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Disbursements will be made in accordance 
with ADB’s Technical Assistance Handbook (2010). The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of 
which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis from by ADB's Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF-other sources). The TA will be carried out until 31 December 2017. 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
31.  The poor coverage and quality of infrastructure services adversely affect the cost of 
doing business and access to services by the population. This leads to increased costs for 
accessing markets, health, and education services as well as high costs for vehicle repair for 
vehicles using deteriorated roads, and high investment cost for individual acquisition of water 
storage and power generation to secure services when the public system is out of service.  
 
32.  Under  the  program,  the  water  tariff  will  reflect  full  operational  and  maintenance 
expenditures, key performance indicators, and regular tariff adjustments.20 The performance risk 
is borne by the private concessionaire, while the government will monitor the concessionaire’s 
contractual service performance obligations. A power distribution tariff will support full cost 
recovery  and  adequate  remuneration  of  power  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution 
companies.21 Tariff setting will be supported by a more independent and transparent PSRC. 
 
B.  Governance 
33.  The government is strengthening its PFM system, primarily through the full rollout of 
program budgeting. The MOEINR, MOTCIT, and SCWE will be capable of executing program 
budgeting,  and  have  strengthened  internal  audit.  While  a  public  expenditure  and  financial 
accountability assessment states that the PFM system performance is robust, weaknesses were 
identified in fiscal discipline, allocation of resources, and cost-effective service delivery.22 The 
government’s Anticorruption Council is responsible for setting anticorruption policies and leading 
related investigations and imposing remedies. However, the work of the council does not appear 
to  be  effective  as  the  council  does  not  meet  regularly  and  has  not  produced  significant 
recommendations for reform. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained to and discussed with the government. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
34.  No adverse impact on poor and vulnerable groups is expected from the policy reforms. 
Improved program budgeting will increase fiscal resources, enabling the government to secure 
adequate development financing, including social expenditures indirectly benefiting the poor. 
Currently no women are represented on boards of government wholly-owned power companies. 
Through this program at least one woman will be appointed to each of these boards to help 
address the gender imbalance and also ensure gender issues are considered at the highest 
levels of these companies. 
                                                
20 Under the lease contract, the government will remain the owner of the water supply system. Major capital works 
will need to be funded by the government. The envisaged water tariff will not cover such costs. 
21 Generation and transmission tariffs exist. However, the lack of a distribution tariff adversely impacts the revenues 
of generation and transmission companies. 
22 Public Expenditure Financial Accountability Secretariat. 2014. Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability 
Assessment Report 2013: Republic of Armenia. Washington, DC.

10 
D.  Safeguards 
35.  The  program  is  classified  category  C  for  impacts  on  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples and complies with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009).  The  program  provides  opportunities  for  introducing  good  practices  for  climate  risk 
management and climate resilience thereby having an attribution to climate adaptation finance. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
36.  Major risks and mitigating measures in the risk assessment and risk management plan 
are summarized in the table.23 The benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs.

V.  ASSURANCES 
37.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the program, which 
are set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $90,000,000 to Armenia for the Infrastructure Sustainability Support Program (Phase 2), 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 15 years, including a 
grace period of 3 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
